record.def: take aback surprise, disconcert. [old english: related to *a2
(pl. -cuses) 1 frame with wires along which beads are slid for calculating. 2 archit. Flat slab on top of a capital. [latin from greek from hebrew]
—adv. In the stern half of a ship. —prep. Nearer the stern than. [from *a2, -baft: see *aft]
1 give up. 2 forsake, desert. 3 (often foll. By to; often refl.) Yield to a passion, another's control, etc. —n. Freedom from inhibitions.  abandonment n. [french: related to *ad-, *ban]
(-sing) (also refl.) Humiliate, degrade.  abasement n. [french: related to *ad-, *base2]
(-ting) make or become less strong etc.; diminish.  abatement n. [french abatre from latin batt(u)o beat]
(pl. -ies) office or jurisdiction of an abbot or abbess. [latin: related to *abbot]
(-ting) shorten, esp. Represent (a word etc.) By a part of it.  abbreviation n. [latin: related to *brief]

(-ding; past abided or rarely abode) 1 (usu. In neg.) Tolerate, endure (can't abide him). 2 (foll. By by) a act in accordance with (abide by the rules). B keep (a promise). 3 archaic remain, continue. [old english a- intensive prefix, *bide]
(pl. -ies) 1 (often foll. By to + infin.) Capacity or power. 2 cleverness, talent. [french: related to *able]
suffix forming nouns of quality from, or corresponding to, adjectives in -able.
Miserable, wretched; degraded; despicable.  abjection n. [latin jacio -ject- throw]
A sweet fruit is grown everywhere on earth. It has many types.
